title: On 29 June 2018, how many public DC Fast Charge electric vehicle charging stations will be available in the United States?
preds: Going all in because there are only two days left.
The number remained stable at 2306 (only one more since 13 May) ; radically revising my previous projections as it is highly unlikely that the number will go over 2400 in 25 days.

I'm really starting to wonder if someone at the DOE is screwing with us because of all the traffic coming to their site from GJOpen. :) The numbers were growing at 1.5 per day all winter and then they ground to a halt at 2302 or 2305 over a month ago.
2 302. The phat lady is warming her vocal chords.
UP to 2306, so 14 added in the past month.
Updating due to slower than expected growth.

2303 listed as in place today, May 13
47 days to go
97/47= 2+ per day opening to meet low basket limit of 2400.
daily average opening has never exceeded 1.1 2319 if you count the "planned" ones. that doesn't count but is a proxy for any likelihood of large short-term surge in "available"
Updating towards lower estimates as no growth occurred since last observation and given that 1/4 of the remaining time-to-census elapsed since then.
Shifting lower due to the slow rate of growth, only up to 2,302 today.
2 302 - glacial pace. Likely to stay below or close to 2 400

Something definitely isn't right with that website.  It was at 2308 on April 26th, then it dropped to 2302 and held steady for over a week until slightly nudging up to 2303.  Meanwhile, every single day for the past 5 weeks it was going up by at least 1-6 per day.  Perhaps the intern got fired? ;)
I am turning pessimistic  over numbers which are kind of hidden (quaterly numbers only compared with monthly statistics earlier ) by GM,  transparency is still the best !

Doesn’t impact this question/timelines but interesting if more fast chargers are located in convenient locations...
https://www.caranddriver.com/news/electrify-americas-speediest-350-kw-fast-chargers-may-be-as-close-as-the-nearest-walmart
2305 as of Apr 29 - increase of 12 in 10days. Might get close to 2400; Requires 95 in 60 days which would be faster than normal pace but sometimes just waiting for inspection...

There were 2080 DC stations in June 2017 - at the time of writing the data suggests there are 2305. We are 2 months away from the census date and my prediction is close to 2700 hence the near-equal split in probability.

The number is starting to surge in fits and starts.  There were 8 new ones between April 8-12, then just 3 new ones between April 17-20, now 9 new ones between April 24-26. All told, the growth rate has been 1.5 new stations per day for the past 21 days for a final number of 2406.
@Chrisp,  thank you for the many interesting insights  and options of view points
At the current rate, we're looking at a final number in the area of 2230, so while it's unlikely we'll climb above 2399 by June 29, it's possible.
Now we're up to 2292, which exceeds the number from March that included planned stations. Go figure. Anyway, 14 added in past month. That's consistent with past few months.

VW says it will have c200 completed by 2nd quarter.  https://electrek.co/2017/04/14/vw-nationwide-150-kw-fast-charging-network-electric-vehicle/ This guy.. (lol) claims there are 2080:  https://electrek.co/2017/06/19/us-electric-vehicle-charging-stations/ 11 months ago.   Which is what.. 10 a month?  While the VW settlement will continue - how much more money will a republican administration push? Study at DOE here:  found High energy stations rarely used. https://www.triplepundit.com/2017/10/u-s-energy-dept-aims-extreme-fast-ev-charging-without-bumping-costs/
And there are no mfg's currently manufacturing cars to the 350EV standard  But even the 350 stations recharge at 19 miles a minutes.   Meaning... to recharge a 300 mile range you're talking 16 minutes.   Cool - but still way slower than filling up.   And the people that can afford the cars will begrudge the time. https://www.nrel.gov/docs/fy17osti/69031.pdf US announces $15 milion grant?  Oooh boy.  15 mil. https://www.greencarreports.com/news/1113514_energy-dept-to-award-15-million-for-very-fast-electric-car-charging VW's CA plans: https://electrek.co/2017/03/15/vw-ev-infrastructure-320-kw-charging-station/
2293 on April 19. Per others - number goes up/down as often as Tesla Model 3 speculation. Going to be close to 2400 at this point but believe will fall short.
No clue what's going on with the website.  Looks like we're back up to 2291 today which logically means we'll be back at 2100 tomorrow.

For some reason over 100 popped up yesterday, so there are now almost 2,300.  However, in the past several at a time have also vanished, and the average daily increase is a couple orders of magnitude lower than this, so I'm staying with the bottom bucket, but inching slightly up owing to cowardice.
...  uuuuuh...    Anyone know why the number all the sudden dropped from 2289 to 2184?https://www.afdc.energy.gov/fuels/electricity_locations.html#/find/nearest?fuel=ELEC&ev_levels=dc_fast

EDIT:  See my most recent forecast above this.   The site updated today and went from 2289 to 2184, rendering the comment below this moot.  
------
The current growth rate is between 1.63 and 1.86 stations per day.  
1.63 if updates to the site are updated in real time, 1.86 if the they occur at midnight. At the rate of 1.63 they'll hit 2416
At the rate of 1.86 they'll hit 2434
As the community has already pointed out (good post by @Okanaganopolis in particular), anything other than the first bin would require an unprecedented rate of installations.
2284 requires almost 1,5 a day until end to breach 2400 - very unlikely. As peers have discussed, sometimes multiple come online in short order as built etc and simply need to be inspected/unveiled.
Based on current numbers they're tracking for 2429, so I'm going to wiggle my numbers a smidgen.

As of end of March I compute 2281 DC Fast Charging stations. 1891 Stations if Tesla stations are not included. 
 Growth rate indicates just touching 2400 is possible assuming Spring means faster completion than winter months.

2276. Going all in from 85-15 given PoT & WoC. #Wok-pot. Might celebrate with an Asian stirfry if I'm right.  Forgot about this Q and should have changed a month ago. Just don't see another 124 (or 5.4%) installed before June 29th or 92 days.   Growth rate isn't high enough and seems like it will conclude at around the 2320 to 2370 mark at most.

If DC fast charging stations remain to be around 15% of the EV station make-up, then we can expect them to be around 2,700 around mid-2018. [18,000*0.15 = 2700] Given the investment in electric vehicles from automakers, it's reasonable to assume that expectations will be beat, BUT this administration is less friendly to EVs than the previous (slight edge to over 2,700).

A graphic from the electrek.co article shows only 2080 DC fast station as of June 2017. According to the DOE site, the current number of stations as of March 26, 2018 is 2279. This averages to 22 new stations being added a month. If this pace continues, roughly 2345 DC Fast Charge stations will be available by the end of June 2018.  It would seem likely that less than 2400 stations will be available, with a slight possibility that this threshold is exceeded.
Skewing the numbers downward a little due to lack of significant increase in numbers in recent weeks.
Shifting lower because we are only up to 2,280 charging stations and the rate of growth just isn't very high.

According to DOE (https://www.afdc.energy.gov/fuels/electricity_locations.html#/analyze?fuel=ELEC&ev_levels=dc_fast) as of March 21, there are 2,237 Fast DC Charging stations.  Just can't see that much growth in the next 100 days, particularly with the winter the NE is having.

About 40 new Stations in the last 40 Days. Around 100 days to go, currently at 2277. A slight seasonal acceleration still does not seem very unplausible, so the second lowest bracket is still in the race.
Whoever is behind this effort, if anyone is, is resting on their laurels.  Resting on electric laurels could be painful, but won't move this number in time for this deadline.
2278. Including planned stations, it's 2283. I downloaded the spreadsheet, which also only lists 5 planned stations before mid-year.

it's leapt to 2277 from two weeks ago. website has also changed 'look", so there may have been a backlog while the site was being upgraded...  122/105 days to go still needs in excess of 1 a day to open. winter slows things... hedging to bucket 2/1

Currently there are 2,277 DC Fast Stations in the US. Mid-2017 there were only about 2080 DC Fast stations.
Growth rate over about 1/2 year of about 10%.
I feel like someone in Vegas set this line because it's going to be extremely close to 2400.
There are almost 2300 stations currently.  There is a small chance that another 200 can come on line in the time frame and a non-zero chance that 400 can come on line
Jump to 2278 and 3.5months to go -requires addition of 1/day to get over 2400. Might make it - suspect there’s a backlog requiring review/inspection...

Noticed we had another big jump from 2236 to 2278.  The last one like that happened in December.  If they continue at that rate, (Which would be one more jump of 40 or so) we'll still come in under 2400.  If it should happen three more times...then I'll be coming in pretty close to dead last.  The data continues to indicate 2400 is a pretty tough number to beat.
it could hit 2400, but seems unlikely.

Going ALL IN. Tiny movements in the last 30 days. As at today, built AND forecast total is up to: 2,245 electric stations. 4 months to go so would need 38 a month to complete to hit 2400. average month has never exceeded 30 since question began.
Fast chargers are rare and public ones - i.e. not tied to a particular manufacturer - rarer still.

Today, there are 2,232 DC FastCharging stations in the US. Demand is there as Tesla drivers can use them in addition to the Tesla Superchargers. Supply is catching up sluggishly. Until the deadline, about 10% more supply can be reasonably expected.
No one uses the ones in local grocery store parking lot.
Based in the number of EVs currently in the road
One thing worrying me, just a little.  Today is Feb 24 and I have seen NO updates to the website's reported numbers since Feb 3.... Hmmm
Note: according to “Alternative Fuels Data Centre”, multiple stations at one location resolve as one. Helps me in keeping to under 2400. Will keep an eye on this one.

Considering they’ve only managed to install 2 in a month and they are behind schedule, find it hard to believe they’ll crack 2400. But perhaps there are a number underway and improved weather will speed things up. Relatively stable/inexpensive oil won’t help though...
There is rapid adoption of charging stations, tesla and beyond
Feb 15 2232 fast charge stations. Maybe a number are in progress or slowdown given winter but slow going...
65% annual growth rate of installed fast chargers extracted from global forecast

I travel very extensively and I have been very conscious of the number of charging stations that I see available and I think this number is extil extremely low and because of the complications of installation it will be a slow progress.
Supply and demand.... there isn't enough demand to warrant that many.
No change - either the info hasn’t been updated or weatheris impacting. Glacial progress.

I was considering some exponential growth of stations in the areas where most of the EV sales are taking place, I have to reduce it substantially, it does seem the present rate of licensing with the present issued permits so far are below past 12 months rate, thus a massive reduction in the forecast. We might have a hard time seen anything above 2700.

Adjustment after looking at consensus and documented base rates by others. Not that extreme yet, since the low current base rate might very well be because of seasonal stops of construction. Also there seem to be some issues with the database.

There seem to be built around 2000 charging stations per year. It was only half of that last year, but there are quite a few fluctuations, so we will go with a possibly slightly to high estimate of 2000 per year. Around 10% of the stations are DC stations, which would yield 200 of those built per year. However, it is likely that a significantly bigger perecentage of the new stations uses the new and better technology, and it could even be, that old stations are being replaced by newer DC ones. So i will go with an estimate of 40% of newly built stations being DC stations and arrive at 800 stations per year. The possible overestimation of the base rate hopefully cancels out with my ignorance of ongoing projects of VW, Tesla and the like to strengthen the infrastructure. 
So i arrive at  a point estimate of 800/12*(4+2/3)=311 new stations until the deadline, which will most likely land in the lower 2400 - 2700 bracket. 
Looking at VWs plans in here, https://electrek.co/2017/04/14/vw-nationwide-150-kw-fast-charging-network-electric-vehicle/ large operations seen to take considerable planning time, why large Deviations up into the highest bracket seem very unlikely.  Note for later: 11.02.2018: 2231  DC stations
The current administration is not favorable to alternative energy,  but manufacturers are fiercely competitive.

The overall growth trend has been well below 1 per day, and especially slow in 2018 (Just 3 added between 5-Jan and 8-Feb). with the figure at 2231 as of 9-Feb-18 (141 days to go), the most likely scenario is <2400.
Fast Charging Stations will not fix the inherent problems with electric cars when fuel cell vehicles can refuel in under 5 minutes with a simple add-on at existing gas stations.
regulatory and infrastructure issues prevent a quick change upward in numbers so I'm locking in the lowest bin

Today (Feb.3.18):  2232  BUILT. (2240 is the number of Built, PLUS Planned stations.)  
Source: the link that solely judges this question, https://www.afdc.energy.gov/fuels/electricity_locations.html (and adjusted for DCFast stations ONLY) : A maximum of 159 more than than are currently BUILT to resolve at Bucket 1:  "Less than 2400".
There are 146 days, including weekends, till end of question.  So you'll need to maintain an AVERAGE growth of "1+ per Day" from NOW till question CLOSE.  Since the beginning, daily average has never maintained that rate of speed. It may get fairly close but unlikely to be anything other than a Bucket 1 win.. My only reticence to be at 100% is possibility of lagtime and an "large update dump" occurring by the major builders like VW (Electrify America) and Tesla. It's in their marketing dept's interest to be proactive with these announcements but who knows...? In any case, no GJP'er should have ANY bet in Bucket 3 and/or 4  on this question. Maybe they're not checking the sole source link that is governing this questions outcome. https://www.afdc.energy.gov/fuels/electricity_locations.html
2232 as of 1 February 2018. Only about 50 added in past 3 months.
Going lower because I just don't see there being enough DC fast chargers given the rate of growth.
VW - Electrify America is too slow.
2232 on Jan 27. About 150 days for 168 chargers. Looking unlikely at this point. Increasing my under 2400 per cent to 90.
Demand for electric vehicles is low
The more available they are, the more likely they will be included in new infrastructure plans

Current numbers are still at 2231, so unless there is amajor tax incentive or infrastructure push (i.e every public building and public park get installed new charging stations) I doubt we’ll see higher numbers.
There are 2231 according to the referenced website.  Growth seems to have slowed, so I think we are in the first two categories. At 10% per year, we would still be in the first category in June.

News today-"Partnering with EV charging companies, PG&E will install 7,500 level 2 charging stations at business customer sites including condominiums, apartment buildings and workplaces across Northern and Central California.
The three-year program officially starts in 2018, and continues through 2020, with a budget of $130 million."
Note those are level 2, the DC Fast chargers are level 3. Maybe the move is toward installation of far cheaper level 2 for charging in 4 to 6 hours.
Well we are up to 2,230 of these chargers so at current rates of growth I estimate we end up at around 2,400 but probably just a little below.

Confirming my current confidence it will close under 2400. Looking into past comments and links by other players: September 18 showed 2178. Today shows 2239 (including "planned") That's 61 in the last 4 months. With 4 months to go that rate could DOUBLE and we'd have a final number under 2400 (2361). Its a race between countries to make the most advancement

Made my preferred split.  Electric car demand turns on oil price, and it still has a ways to climb, and new stations would take some time to install, especially in places where the market can support it.  Cost disease at work, basically.

I've been using the growth in Supercharger locations in the prediction model to offset what appears to be a lag in reporting to the DOE.  However, there was recently a significant weekly jump in the DOE database (36) so I'm going to stop using the Supercharger numbers as a hedge under the assumption that the DOE was brought up to date.  That results in a higher probability in the <2400 category. I still think the DOE numbers are wrong, but I think the chances of them fully correcting that error before the end date are low.
There are over 16,000 charging station, out of those, close to 2300 are DC fast chargers. Many more are currently under construction.

2230 as of 8 Jan 2018.

If they add another hundred or more before the question deadline, that could push us into the second bracket. But progress seems to be slower than that.
Per “ coffeeforecasts” and US dept of energy there are 2230 today (Jan 6) and they are adding about one per day. Will be close to 2400.

pushback Fleetcarma: "The Drawbacks of a Fast Charge As might be expected, installing a public DCQC costs considerably more than adding a Level 2 charging station. First, there’s the cost of the station itself, which has decreased in some instances by more than two thirds over the last five years. Where the earliest CHAdeMO charging units could cost upwards of $35,000 when the technology first hit the market, Nissan currently offers one for less than $10,000. BMW sells its CCS charger for less than $7,000. Unfortunately, stations themselves are just fraction of the total cost burden associated with installing a DCQC. A 2014 survey by the Rocky Mountain Institute placed the real price of each new quick charge station at $50,000 – $100,000. Labor, permitting and the installation of a 480-volt transformer ($10,000 – $25,000) accounted for roughly two thirds of the final cost. Using this math, it would require an investment of as much as $600 million just to cover the state of California with enough quick chargers to match Japan’s concentration— and that’s ignoring the added cost of providing for multiple standards at each station. Then there’s the consumer cost of the DCQC charge port on the car itself. More than half of EVs with quick charge capability offer it as an option and not a standard feature—usually adding upwards of $700 to a model’s sticker price. Until quick-charge stations become more common, there are few non-Tesla drivers for whom that add-on makes a ton of fiscal sense." Lobbying to get installation/permit costs down but momentum for that not in present US federal government so erring on lower side

I've been tracking the Tesla Supercharger site since mid Sept.  While the # of supercharging stations has been steadily increasing from 391 to the current 440 (an increase of 49), the number listed as 'Coming Soon' has been decreasing from 489 to 435 (a decrease of 54), meaning they've reduced their expectations by 5 superchargers.  It doesn't affect my forecast, but it's an interesting  little nugget to keep in the back of my mind.

Based on the cost of installing these vs. others (much higher for DC Fast), the (presumed -- I didn't do enough research to back this up) higher cost of maintenance on gasoline pumps and the likelihood that older pumps would just not be replaced in favor of adding electric chargers. A gas station, hotel, corporate office park looking toward the future might add electric chargers as a result of the swing automakers are making toward electric. For offices it's a perk for businesses/their employees, and might also provide them some tax breaks (depending upon future policy and states).  That said, I don't think the growth will necessarily accelerate yet, as the hope would be that the cost comes down first, before the tipping point. If I were considering installing, I might try to push it off a year or perhaps two to let the price drop, banking on the current administration not changing tax credits (I don't believe there is anything related in the current tax bill on the table)
I think the future is inductive charging, not DC charging.

Will there be a 10% increase, yes.
Will there be a 50% increase, no.
Where it falls in between in the question.
by the rate of bulding those stations it should be around 2,400.

2185 as of 22 October. Only 2 added in past 2 weeks. If this pace continues, it will come in under 2400. But the VW court settlement includes plans for 200 DC fast chargers within period of question, and Tesla has several hundred planned Supercharger locations. No idea when they will be installed. But these things keep me leaning toward the second bracket.
It will either take off or have little adoption, based on incentives. I hope it takes off.
2146 in planning or better at this point.  GM announced electric fleet recently.  Highly likely 2.4-2.7k by mid 2018.
There are currently 2,184 electric stations.  This is my preliminary prediction.  I am trying to find data on how many are going up per month.

First, I tried finding a current approximate ratio of electric vehicles to charging stations.  Based on that ratio, I tried to find out how many new charging stations might be built based on the estimated growth in the ownership of electric vehicle.  I assumed that a major factor in deciding whether to build fast charging stations vs conventional charging stations is their cost. (Eg. If fast charging stations cost 9 times more than conventional charging stations, then only 1 of 10 new charging stations built would be fast charging stations.)
________________________________________________
There are approximately 31 electric vehicles to 1 charging stations. Assuming that electric car sales is at 7500 a month, within 8 months there would be 60000 new electric vehicles. This means that roughly 2000 new charging stations will be built. Assumong that 20% of all new charging stations will be fast charging stations, that would mean 400 new fast charging stations. Adding the 400 new fast harging stations to the existing ones gives approximately 2400. It could be more or less depending on the actual electric car ownership growth and governmental policies and development projects.  Based on my current assumptions, it is very unlikely that there will be more than 31pp charging stations.
Thank you, @Okanaganopolis, for the link to this guide to fast charging stations at https://www.fleetcarma.com/dc-fast-charging-guide/
found the article that supports my newer pessimism. pretty good read... the upshot to me is that its gonna be a little slower than u may think... https://www.fleetcarma.com/dc-fast-charging-guide/
shifting lower. maybe more so in coming weeks as i try and get better data sources than the one site we're scoring "from". my gut is strongly leaning towards "less than 2400"

Currently: 2178 DC Fast stations
YoY growth has some mixed numbers - revenue expectations for semiconductors related to DC Fast chargers is pegged at 90% yoy growth, with more conservative station growth rates between 40-80%.
Chevy, VW, Audi, Nissan all releasing new cars that leverage the standard, Tesla 3 not a meaningful player in this time frame.
Also possibly some lag in reporting through the website.

The DOE site we're using for tracking and scoring seems to have some issues.  (The number of DC Fast Chargers has dropped from 2181 to 2179 in the last week...What's that about?)   I downloaded their data file, and there are so many blank fields across so many columns that trying to use it to determine what is going in the real world is problematic.   If the DOE site is being this poorly managed, it may end up lagging the count of actual chargers in the field on June 29, meaning correct answers may appear too high and end up being scored as wrong because of problems with the site.  Yet another variable to keep in mind.

Not a fast rate of increase.  Additional chargers may be located at existing stations rather than at new sites Misc. stats from various sources:
US fast charge stations: 12/12: 686, 9/17: 2180
Tesla Fast Charge Stations: 6/17: 386
CHAdeMO stations: 3/12: 355+, 5/15: 1,337
Progress in electro cars is fast, although limited to urban areas.
Tesla will overdrive it.  Subsidies will continue.  Costs come down.
It will take a longer time than expected.  It will be 2% of fleet so at most 3-5% of gas station count
this is necessary for US infrastructure an E-Car drivers

After averaging the rate of new charging stations per in the United States, about  5,505 charging stations are added each year. Last year was a low year at  2,494. I hypothesize that this is not a sign of slowdown but I'm guessing that as Tesla and other new models from other manufactures (as sales are increasing, but I haven't explored that angle yet) will only drive the average upward in the remainder of the decade, and last's year slowdown will only means that the market needs to correct. By simply going with "guess same rate of change" which for the most part is a good strategy you're going to arrive at well over 3100. The percentages were just guesswork, but I hope to have a better method later. I'll probably revise when I examine the relationship between sales and stations later but I don't have time at the moment. I expect it will further increase my confidence in aiming high but until I do the math I'm not that confident.

Another drag on putting in charging stations is early obsolescence of the existing tech.  Wireless charging is already available for the home that is close to an L2 station in terms of charging time.   Once someone develops a wireless fast-charger, you no longer have to worry about what kind of connector is on the end of the wire 'hose'.   And, in the near future, autonomous vehicles can drive themselves to a wireless charger meaning the owner doesn't have to be present during the charging, making them much more convenient.   I wouldn't want to be the business invested in dvd players when all of my customers are streaming.

2178 as of 18 Sept 2017. Not sure at what rate the expansion is taking place, but this article is from 17 June. At that time, there were 2080 DC Fast charging stations. So an increase of about 100 in 3 months.  https://electrek.co/2017/06/19/us-electric-vehicle-charging-stations/ Nine months to go. So 300 more? VW will be installing a network of charging stations as part of its court settlement. According to their plan, there should be 200 more charging stations operational by the end of this question period (see page 8 of embedded document at link below). These will be 150 and 300 kW chargers. https://electrek.co/2017/04/14/vw-nationwide-150-kw-fast-charging-network-electric-vehicle/ Not sure if Tesla makes a difference here or not, as I don't know how they are being counted by the US Dept. of Energy. I don't believe their Superchargers are included, but I don't know what is.

I will admit I'm having no luck finding a model to work from.  My guess is the ROI is not sufficient for most businesses to install a fast charger yet.   When McDonalds starts to show an interest in making an agreement with someone like Chargepoint (Or more likely, creating their own operation), costs of the chargers will start to drop and FOMO will motivate other nationwide fast-food and fast-casual restaurants to start their own installations.  But I think that is still several years away.

This is more of an initial guess, admittedly based on initial reactions when reading the question. Recent buzz surrounding EVs in the US makes me a little more inclined to believe that the trend will continue/increase, but I'm hesitant to think that the number will increase from 2,178 to 3,101+ in just over 9 months.
I believe there will be a spurt of growth in DC charging stations. Especially in areas like Atlanta and California.
A couple of hundred from the Volkswagen settlement driven investment probably come online by then, plus maybe a 100 or so from Tesla, that should be the bulk of it.

The growth of DC fast charge stations has been sadly slow in the country, no doubt due to the small number of cars that can handle DC fast charge stations. While I think Tesla is going to grow fast in the next year (although by fast I mean to 100,000 vehicles) I don't think the DC fast charge infrastructure expands significantly or quickly.
With over 2000 in 2016 and dramatic increases in 2017 and 2018 growth should be solid.
